text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This IRM contains the following material changes:

IRM Brief Description 8.26.2 Editorial, grammatical, formatting changes were made throughout this reorganized IRM 8.26.2.1 Added and updated Program Scope and Objectives and its related subsections to comply with the Deputy Commissioners of Services and Enforcement and Opera- tions Support memo dated September 14, 2016, entitled Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls 8.26.2.2 Updated the General Provisions of the process 8.26.2.3 Updated Settlement Authority to add reference to Delegation Order 8-9 8.26.2.6 Updated the deﬁnition of Excluded Cases 8.26.2.6.4 Removed the APS carding procedures, which are contained in IRM 8.20.5 8.26.2.9 Emphasized the procedural requirements in cases settled using Appeals delegated settlement authority 8.26.2.10 Clariﬁed in Appeals’ Settlements that the FTS Official should utilize his/her authority under Delegation Order 8-9 when needed to effect an agreement between SB/SE, the taxpayer and the FTS Official that is based on the hazards of litigation 8.26.2.14 Clariﬁed Conﬁdentiality in FTS within FTS 8.26.2.13 Added in Unresolved Issues that post-appeals mediation (PAM) is not available for any issue considered during the FTS process if the parties fail to resolve the issue or if either party withdraws after the start of the process 8.26.2.16 Added in Closing Procedures - FTS Official that the FTS Official must send the FTS Package to the ATM for an ACAPDATE, and that an ATM’s signature is not required on Form 5402 8.26.2.16 Removed the requirement in Customer Satisfaction Survey to complete and secure Customer Satisfaction surveys
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS This IRM supersedes IRM 8.26.2 dated September 27, 2012.
Appeals
Track Settlement for Small Business/Self (SB/SE) Taxpayers 8.26.2
Taxpayers

) A primary objective of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is to resolve tax troversies at the lowest level without sacriﬁcing the quality and integrity of those determinations. Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) programs this objective. Small Business Self Employed (SB/SE) Fast Track (FTS) is one such ADR process. (
) The goals and process time frames in SB/SE FTS provide taxpayers more timely resolution of their tax dispute. (
) FTS takes place while the case is in SB/SE’s jurisdiction. (
) The entire process is estimated to be completed within a goal of
days beginning from the date the Form
, Application for Fast Track Settlement is accepted by the Office of Appeals (Appeals) to the date the is closed on Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS). (

) FTS beneﬁts the taxpayer and the Service because it: • resolves issues at the earliest stage possible • makes use of Appeals’ settlement authority during the Exam • reduces overall case cycle time • reduces taxpayer burden • reduces resource needs for the Service (
) The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
, directed the IRS to implement procedures to allow a broader use of early referral and ADR programs. (
) Rev. Proc.
C.B.
, implemented a fast track program for taxpayers in the Large and Mid-Sized Business Division (now Large Business and International Division). Announcement
, IRB
, relied on the provisions of Rev. Proc.
and established FTS as a two year pilot program to expedite case resolution and expand range of dispute resolution options available to SB/SE taxpayers. (
) Announcement
IRB
piloted the program and ment
, IRB
, extended the pilot. News Release
expanded SB/SE FTS nationwide and Rev. Proc.
I.R.B. formally establishes the program. (

) Appeals Policy and SB/SE Policy jointly administer the SB/SE FTS The executives with program oversight are: • Appeals - Director Case and Operations Support • SB/SE - Director Examination Headquarters (

) Using Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) data, Appeals and disseminates monthly reports on ADR initiatives. These reports include full year performance and year-to-date comparisons of closures, receipts, average days to settle and close, etc. for each ADR initiative. The reports contain data for the total life of each Initiative, as well as, key program tion. Internal Revenue Manual

Rev. Proc. 2003-40, 2003-1 C.B. 1044, implemented a fast track settlement program for taxpayers in the Large and Mid-Sized Business Division (now the Large Business and International Division). Announcement 2006-61, 2006-36 IRB 390, relied on the provisions of Rev. Proc. 2003-40 and established SB/SE FTS as a two year pilot program to expedite case resolution and expand the range of dispute resolution options available to SB/SE taxpayers.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program
(2) Appeals shares the monthly reports with its leadership and key Appeals stake-
Term Acronym Alternative Dispute Resolution ADR Fast Track Settlement FTS FTS Appeals Official FTS Official Other Common Appeals See IRM 8.1.1-1 Acronyms
Fast Track Settlement FTS FTS Appeals Official FTS Official Other Common Appeals See IRM
Acronyms Additional FTS program information can be found: • Pub

- Fast Track Settlement - A Process for Prompt Resolution Small Business Self Employed Tax Issues • Appeals SB/SE Fast Track Settlement website located at web.irs.gov/tech_services/adr/fasttrack-sbse.htm FTS is an ADR service offered by the IRS for the purpose of enabling SB/SE Field and Specialty Examination functions, taxpayers, and Appeals to work together to resolve disputed issues while the case is in SB/SE’s jurisdiction. FTS may apply when SB/SE and the taxpayer have exhausted existing issue resolution strategies within SB/SE, including the Group Manager’s (GM) con- ference, and now want to use mediation to reach resolution. An Appeals Officer trained in mediation techniques serves as the mediator, or FTS Appeals Official (FTS Official). The FTS Official will ﬁrst use mediation techniques to facilitate settlement discussion between SB/SE and the If resolution is not reached through mediation, the FTS Official may propose settlement, but such proposal is not imposed on either party. FTS allows the parties to utilize Appeals’ settlement authority under Order

when needed to effect an agreement between SB/SE, the taxpayer and the FTS Official that is based on the hazards of litigation. See IRM Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Delegation of Authorities for the Appeals Process, and IRM

, Conference and Settlement Practices - Reaching Settlement and Securing an Appeals Agreement Form. If a resolution is not reached using FTS, a taxpayer retains the right to traditional Appeals consideration. Post-appeals mediation, however, is not available for any issue considered during the FTS process if the parties fail to resolve the issue or if either party withdraws after the start of the process. Track Settlement for Small Business/Self (SB/SE) Taxpayers 8.26.2
) Delegation Order
(IRM
) contains the IRS Commissioner’s of settlement authority to Grade
and
Appeals Officers assigned Authority FTS Officials for SB/SE FTS cases. (

) This delegation of settlement authority includes the responsibility of the Official to arrive at the ﬁnal disposition from the Government’s perspective, approving the ﬁnal settlement in accordance with the delegated authority, executing the appropriate closing documents. This authority may not be re- delegated. (

) The FTS session includes the taxpayer and the SB/SE representatives with decision making authority and the information and expertise necessary to Process assist the parties and the FTS Official during the negotiation process. All ticipants actively contribute to the resolution of the case. (

) The FTS Official has delegated settlement authority and the ability to offer settlement in both factual and legal issues in the event the parties cannot reach settlement through the use of mediation techniques. Neither party is obligated to accept the settlement proposal offered by the mediator. (

) FTS is generally available for non-docketed SB/SE cases with no regard to dollar amount. The case must have: • Factual and legal issues • Some basis in fact and or law for the conclusions reached • Necessary referrals, technical advice, Counsel Advice and valuation reports • No signiﬁcant unresolved factual differences between SB/SE and taxpayer’s position • Issues for which SB/SE and the taxpayer have exhausted available issue resolution strategies including the Group Manager’s and now want to use mediation to reach resolution (
) If an issue is determined not to be eligible for SB/SE FTS, all issues in the case are not eligible for SB/SE FTS. (
) FTS is not available for:
Factual and legal issues
Some basis in fact and or law for the conclusions reached
Necessary referrals, technical advice, Counsel Advice and valuation reports
No signiﬁcant unresolved factual differences between SB/SE and the taxpayer’s position
Issues for which SB/SE and the taxpayer have exhausted available issue resolution strategies including the Group Manager’s and now want to use mediation to reach resolution
a. Cases in which SB/SE FTS is not appropriate under either
U.S.C. § or
U.S.C. §

, which provide the general authority and guidelines use of alternative dispute resolution in the administrative process; b. Cases in which the taxpayer did not act in good faith during the audit process, such as, but not limited to, cases in which the taxpayer failed cooperate or unduly delayed the audit process; c. Correspondence examination cases worked solely in a Campus/Service Center site; d. Partnership cases under the Tax Equity & Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA); e. Collection cases: Collection Due Process, Collection Appeals Program, Offer-In-Compromise, and Trust Fund Recovery Penalty; f. Issues designated for litigation; g. Issues docketed in any court;

Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program h. Issues precluded from settlement by previous closing agreements, res judicata, or controlling Supreme Court precedent; i. Issues for which SB/SE FTS would not be in the interest of sound tax ad- ministration. For example, issues common to issues in litigation for which it is important that the IRS maintain a consistent position, or issues common to issues in litigation over which the Department of Justice has jurisdiction; j. Frivolous issues, such as, but not limited to, those identiﬁed in section
of Rev. Proc.
I.R.B.

, or the corresponding provision of any successor guidance; k. “Whipsaw” issues, or issues for which resolution with respect to one party might result in inconsistent treatment in the absence of participation of another party. Examples include, but are not limited to, issues on a joint return where both spouses do not agree to participate in the same FTS Session, or where one spouse is claiming innocent spouse treatment under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §
; l. Issues for which the taxpayer has submitted a request for competent authority assistance. See section
of Rev. Proc.
I.R.B.
, or the corresponding provision of any successor guidance, which describes the procedures of the U.S. competent authority for coordi- nation with IRS examination proceedings. Under section
) of Rev. Proc.

, the taxpayer’s access to U.S. competent authority assis- tance is generally not affected by the taxpayer’s pursuit of alternative dispute resolution programs under the jurisdiction of IRS Examination, including SB/SE FTS. Taxpayers are cautioned that if resolution of the taxpayer’s competent authority issue (as deﬁned in Rev. Proc.
) is reached through the SB/SE FTS process, the taxpayer’s access to U.S. competent authority assistance will be determined in accordance with sections
) and
) of Rev. Proc.

If a taxpayer enters into a closing agreement (including settlement through the SB/SE FTS process) and then requests competent authority assistance, the U.S. competent authority will endeavor only to obtain a correlative adjustment from the treaty country and will not take any actions that would otherwise change the settlement. See section
) of Rev. Proc.

If a taxpayer enters into SB/SE FTS, the taxpayer generally may not request competent authority assistance until the SB/SE FTS process is complete. However, the taxpayer may ﬁle a protective claim with the competent authority in the form of a competent authority request or a letter while SB/SE FTS is pending if a protective claim is necessary to keep open the period of limi- tations in a foreign country. See section
of Rev. Proc.

If these requirements have been satisﬁed and a protective claim has been ﬁled, the taxpayer must notify the U.S. competent authority that the case is in alternative dispute resolution in SB/SE FTS. In addition, the taxpayer must notify the FTS Appeals Official that a protective claim has been ﬁled and that the provisions have been satisﬁed. The U.S. competent authority will suspend action on the case until SB/SE FTS is complete; m. Issues outside SB/SE jurisdiction; or n. Issues that have been otherwise identiﬁed in subsequent guidance issued by the IRS as excluded from the SB/SE FTS process. (
) If any one issue is determined not to be eligible for SB/SE FTS, all issues in the case shall not be eligible for SB/SE FTS.

) The Appeals Team Manager (ATM) and the GM may agree to consider or cases otherwise not eligible for FTS depending on individual and the operational needs of the case. (
) Either the taxpayer or SB/SE can initiate FTS; however, both parties must agree to the process. (
) Ideally, FTS is initiated on fully developed eligible cases: a. Field Exam cases: generally prior to the
-day letter b. Office Audit/Exam cases: at the time the taxpayer requests an Appeals conference In either instance, the FTS case is referred as soon as possible, but prior to the issuance of a
-day letter. (
) An issue cannot be fully developed prior to the receipt of all necessary referrals, technical advice, Counsel advice, valuation reports, or other documentation. (
) If the case meets the eligibility requirements in Sec.
, the examiner and/or the GM will discuss FTS with the taxpayer, explain the roles and re- sponsibilities of each party, and the expectations and beneﬁts of the (
) SB/SE and the taxpayer will jointly complete Form
, Application for Track Settlement. (
) The Form
must be signed by the taxpayer, the examiner and the designee. A Territory Manager’s (TM) signature is not required on the
for an SB/SE FTS case. (
) The taxpayer must provide the examiner with a brief, written statement of facts along with a statement of his/her position. (
) If the Form

is executed by a person pursuant to a Power of executed by the taxpayer, that Power of Attorney must express the grant of authority to consent to disclose the taxpayer’s returns and return mation by the Service to third parties. A copy of the Power of Attorney attached to the application. Note: The Form

, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative, not authorize the representative to disclose the taxpayer’s returns and information pertaining to the issues being considered in the FTS process those persons named on the application as participants in the process, unless speciﬁcally added in Section
of Part I of the form.
The Appeals Team Manager (ATM) and the GM may agree to consider issues or cases otherwise not eligible for FTS depending on individual circumstances and the operational needs of the case.
SB/SE and the taxpayer will jointly complete Form 14017, Application for Fast
The taxpayer must provide the examiner with a brief, written statement of the facts along with a statement of his/her position.
The GM will review the case to ensure the issues are fully developed; the examiner considered all information; and the case contains properly docu
mented lead sheets and workpapers supporting the examiner’s position.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (

) The GM should deny an FTS application if the taxpayer is speciﬁcally and therefore does not qualify for FTS, was uncooperative during the audit process, did not respond to document requests, or did not submit an written response to the proposed issues. (

) A request for FTS that is denied by the GM, other than the deﬁned excluded cases, requires review and concurrence by the SB/SE TM. A decision by the SB/SE TM not to accept a case into FTS is ﬁnal. SB/SE will notify the of the denial. (
) SB/SE will send the approved SB/SE FTS Package, which includes the Form

, properly documented lead sheets and workpapers supporting of Incoming examiner’s position, and the taxpayer’s written position and response, to the ATM FTS Point of Contact (POC) at the local servicing Appeals office. (
) All documents in the SB/SE FTS Package are available to all parties at the session. (

) SB/SE and Appeals may use local procedures to meet the FTS time frames and enable effective communication between the functions. Example: SB/SE will fax the approved SB/SE FTS Package to the ATM FTS or send the documents via secure e-mail. SB/SE will not send the ad- ministrative ﬁle. (
) Appeals will date stamp the Form
on the date received. (
) Within
business days of receipt, the ATM will conﬁrm SB/SE’s that the case eligibility requirements are met. Acceptance (
) Upon the ATM’s acceptance of a case for FTS, the ATM will conﬁrm that all issues and claims were raised, all relevant information disclosed, and the is ready for resolution. (
) If accepted, and within
business days of receipt, the ATM will assign the case to an FTS Official. the case (
) The ATM will give Account and Processing Support (APS) a copy of the
, the name of the FTS Official assigned to the case, and the relevant information for input into ACDS. (
) If the ATM determines the case is speciﬁcally excluded from FTS, the ATM notify the SB/SE GM within
business days of receipt, provide the basis That Do Not the denial, and return the “SB/SE FTS Package” to SB/SE, who will notify or are Denied taxpayer of the reason for denial. (
) If the case meets the eligibility requirements for FTS, but the ATM denies the application for another reason, the ATM will notify the SB/SE GM within
business days of receipt, provide the basis for the denial, and return the SB/SE FTS Package to SB/SE. Appeals will notify the taxpayer of the for denial. (

a. numerous issues, whether simple or complex, which will require than
days to resolve; b. SB/SE or the taxpayer is unable to meet during the
day time c. the issues are high proﬁle or sensitive. (
) A taxpayer is not entitled to administrative or judicial review of the decision to accept a case into the SB/SE FTS program. (
) Within

business days of case assignment, the FTS Official will: a. contact the taxpayer and SB/SE to start the planning process. b. identify, determine and conﬁrm the participants and ensure that all decision-making parties will be present during the session. To facilitate resolution, the mediator should encourage the taxpayer’s participation even if the taxpayer is represented. c. request additional information from either party to have full of the issues and will share any information received with all parties to the session. d. schedule the session at the servicing Appeals Office or at another site agreeable to the parties and will consider meeting at a location has the least cost or impact to the Service. This could mean the FTS Official will travel to the examiner’s Post of Duty (POD). The FTS should consult with his/her ATM to make this decision, be ﬂexible in the meeting location, and involve the SB/SE GM and examiner in the decision. .
a. contact the taxpayer and SB/SE to start the planning process. b. identify, determine and conﬁrm the participants and ensure that all decision

making parties will be present during the session. To facilitate resolution, the mediator should encourage the taxpayer’s participation even if the taxpayer is represented. c. request additional information from either party to have full of the issues and will share any information received with all parties to the session. d. schedule the session at the servicing Appeals Office or at another site agreeable to the parties and will consider meeting at a location that has the least cost or impact to the Service. This could mean the FTS Official will travel to the examiner’s Post of Duty (POD). The FTS Official should consult with his/her ATM to make this decision, be ﬂexible in the meeting location, and involve the SB/SE GM and examiner in the decision. .
The FTS Official will: a. use a Form

, Fast Track Session Report to assist in planning session; to list all issues to be considered including a description of the issues and the amounts in dispute; to report on developments during session; and to record and ﬁnalize the disposition of issues b. lead the session and ensure all parties are active participants with equal voices c. not act in a traditional Appeals role, but use an interest-based approach facilitate a settlement of the issues between the parties d. conduct joint sessions with all parties and/or separate meetings as priate e. use various methods and mediation techniques to meet the needs and circumstances of each case, which could include frank discussions the merits of each argument, and settlement authority when warranted f. attempt to bring the parties to a mutual resolution of the issues If no resolution is reached between SB/SE and the taxpayer, the FTS Official may use his/her settlement authority to propose a settlement based on an sessment of the hazards of litigation. Generally, the FTS Official will consider only those issues outlined in the Session Report, except by mutual agreement of the parties. It is expected that the examiner and taxpayer have raised all issues, claims, and presented all documentation before the FTS Application package is submitted to Appeals.
a. use a Form

, Fast Track Session Report to assist in planning the session; to list all issues to be considered including a description of the issues and the amounts in dispute; to report on developments during the session; and to record and ﬁnalize the disposition of issues b. lead the session and ensure all parties are active participants with equal voices c. not act in a traditional Appeals role, but use an interest-based approach facilitate a settlement of the issues between the parties d. conduct joint sessions with all parties and/or separate meetings as appro- priate e. use various methods and mediation techniques to meet the needs and circumstances of each case, which could include frank discussions about the merits of each argument, and settlement authority when warranted f. attempt to bring the parties to a mutual resolution of the issues
Generally, the FTS Official will consider only those issues outlined in the Session Report, except by mutual agreement of the parties.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) If the taxpayer and or SB/SE presents new information related to the issues during the session and the parties agree that the process will not be beyond the goal of
days, the FTS process can continue. (

) If the parties determine that the process will be delayed beyond the goal of days, the FTS Official will consider terminating or postponing the session both parties have had adequate time to review and evaluate the new tion. (
) If the session is terminated, the case is removed from FTS and the must reapply if he or she wants to participate in SB/SE FTS. (
) If after assignment, it is determined that the case is not ready for FTS or is a change in the status of the case, Appeals and SB/SE will discuss with- drawal of the case from FTS. (
) In the event of withdrawal, the FTS Official will notify the taxpayer and return the Application Package to SB/SE, and follow closing procedures in
) A taxpayer can withdraw from FTS at any time by providing written notice Appeals and SB/SE. (

Role in the • include the SB/SE GM or his/her designee, the examiner, and/or who have knowledge and expertise and who will contribute to issue resolution. • have decision making authority to enter into a resolution during the session. (

, Closing on Final Determination Covering Speciﬁc Matters, if applicable. b. The FTS Official must prepare an Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM). (

-AD, Offer of Waiver of Restrictions on Assessment and Collection of Deﬁciency in Tax and to Accept Overassessment and Form

Track Settlement for Small Business/Self (SB/SE) Taxpayers 8.26.2

a. If the TM concurs with the GM’s rejection of the settlement, and an ac- ceptable alternative settlement cannot be reached, Appeals will close FTS case as unagreed. b. If the TM agrees with the settlement proposal, the case is closed based on that proposal. c. The FTS Official will secure the appropriate (Special Appeals Form (AD) or Form

Closing Agreement, if required) documents and forward them to SB/SE, who will close the administrative ﬁle using their standard case closing procedures. On Joint Committee cases, Appeals does not execute an AD type waiver closing agreement until cleared by Joint Committee. Upon reaching an agreement, a Form
, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo is prepared

“This case may not be closed until Joint Committee approval is received. Upon receipt of the Joint Committee letter, Appeals will execute a closing agreement and the case may then proceed through SB/SE closing procedures.”
The FTS Official must prepare a Form

for every FTS case and the issues and adjustment dollars in dispute. The report is used to assist planning the session, to report on developments during the session, and record and ﬁnalize the disposition of the issues. The FTS Official will solicit the taxpayer, representative, if applicable, and SE’s signatures on the report; give all session participants a signed copy; explain that the resolution is not ﬁnal until the necessary closing waivers are signed. The signed Session Report represents the parties’ faith intention to resolve the issues addressed in the report in accordance the terms agreed upon. Form

is not a waiver of restrictions on assessment; does not consents to extend the statute of limitations; and does not start the any statute of limitations. The signature of an IRS Official on the Session Report does not preclude the reopening of the case under Policy
For all issues coordinated as either an Industry Specialty Program (ISP) Appeals Coordinated Issues (ACI), Appeals will follow the procedures in

, Review and Concurrence Procedures. To meet the requirements that all decision-makers attend the FTS Session that Compliance Coordinated Issues/ACI issues are subject to the review concurrence, the Technical Specialist (Technical Guidance or International) serve as a team member and participate in the FTS Session with the and SB/SE. If, for whatever reason, the Technical Specialist does not pate in the FTS session, the settlement of the ISP/ACI issue remains to the review and concurrence.
(06-23-2017) Form 14000 Fast Track Session Report

planning the session, to report on developments during the session, and to record and ﬁnalize the disposition of the issues. The FTS Official will solicit the taxpayer, representative, if applicable, and SB/ SE’s signatures on the report; give all session participants a signed copy; explain that the resolution is not ﬁnal until the necessary closing documents waivers are signed. The signed Session Report represents the parties’ good faith intention to resolve the issues addressed in the report in accordance the terms agreed upon. Form
is not a waiver of restrictions on assessment; does not terminate

The FTS Official will solicit the taxpayer, representative, if applicable, and SB/ SE’s signatures on the report; give all session participants a signed copy; and explain that the resolution is not ﬁnal until the necessary closing documents or waivers are signed. The signed Session Report represents the parties’ good faith intention to resolve the issues addressed in the report in accordance with the terms agreed upon.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) If any issue(s) remain unresolved, the FTS case is closed on ACDS, and SB/SE will begin their “Unagreed” closing process. (
) A taxpayer retains all traditional appeal rights. (
) The FTS Official will destroy any notes created during the session when he/ she closes the case. (
) Unagreed cases coming to Appeals that previously participated in SB/SE FTS are assigned to a different Appeals Officer. (

) If a resolution is not reached using FTS, a taxpayer retains the right to traditional Appeals consideration. Post-appeals mediation, however, is not available for any issue considered during the FTS process if the parties fail to resolve the issue or if either party withdraws after the start of the process. , I.R.B.
and Rev. Proc.

) The SB/SE FTS process is conﬁdential and all information and communica- tions made during the SB/SE FTS process (both oral and written) are both taxpayer return information and dispute resolution communications subject to restrictions on disclosure. See IRC §
and

) In executing the Form
, the taxpayer consents to the disclosure by the IRS of the taxpayer’s returns and return information incident to the settlement process to any participant or observer for the taxpayer. (

) If the application is executed by a person pursuant to a Power of Attorney executed by the taxpayer, that Power of Attorney must clearly express the payer’s grant of authority consenting to disclosure of his/her returns and information by the IRS to third parties, and a copy of the Power of Attorney must be attached to the Application. (

) The prohibition against ex parte communications between Appeals and other IRS employees does not apply to the communications arising in SB/SE FTS. This is because the FTS Official is not acting in his/her settlement role and jurisdiction of the case remains with SB/SE. See Rev.
I.R.B.
, for guidance on ex parte communications. (

) On SB/SE FTS cases returned for traditional Appeals consideration, ex parte restrictions are not imposed on intra-Appeals communications. Appeals agement will take appropriate measures to ensure these cases are handled fairly and impartially. Ex-parte restrictions will apply to communication between Appeals and other IRS originating functions, including SB/SE.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program
If any issue(s) remain unresolved, the FTS case is closed on ACDS, and SB/SE will begin their “Unagreed” closing process.
